content.body: Is there any mechanism to enforce subresource integrity upon a document, such that one can know that a document-like entity (e.g. an iframe or Document object) was initialized from a resource with a given content hash?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Is there any mechanism to enforce subresource integrity upon a document, such that one can know that a document-like entity (e.g. an iframe or Document object) was initialized from a resource with a given content hash?

content.body: Justin Martin: no and no plans for that either at this point that I know of
content.formatted_body: Justin Martin: no and no plans for that either at this point that I know of

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Justin Martin: no and no plans for that either at this point that I know of
Justin Martin: no and no plans for that either at this point that I know of

content.body: Domenic: to be clear, I agree that ideally <link rel=preload> does not do type-specific fetching, but how is it not a layering violation for `fetch()` to act on `Link` headers? At that point it would no longer be the lowest-level primitive we could offer. Definitely seems counter to its design goals.
content.formatted_body: Domenic: to be clear, I agree that ideally <link rel=preload> does not do type-specific fetching, but how is it not a layering violation for fetch() to act on Link headers? At that point it would no longer be the lowest-level primitive we could offer. Definitely seems counter to its design goals.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Domenic: to be clear, I agree that ideally <link rel=preload> does not do type-specific fetching, but how is it not a layering violation for `fetch()` to act on `Link` headers? At that point it would no longer be the lowest-level primitive we could offer. Definitely seems counter to its design goals.

Domenic: to be clear, I agree that ideally <link rel=preload> does not do type-specific fetching, but how is it not a layering violation for fetch() to act on Link headers? At that point it would no longer be the lowest-level primitive we could offer. Definitely seems counter to its design goals.

content.body: fetch() is already not the lowest-level primitive; it builds on top of HTTP which has a bunch of header-triggered behaviors (including further fetches), like Location, CORS, etc.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: fetch() is already not the lowest-level primitive; it builds on top of HTTP which has a bunch of header-triggered behaviors (including further fetches), like Location, CORS, etc.

content.body: Link being another one of those seems reasonable to me; there's a bit of an IETF/WHATWG mess where IETF doesn't have the toolbox to specify Link caches in proper detail but that's fine, we can do it.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Link being another one of those seems reasonable to me; there's a bit of an IETF/WHATWG mess where IETF doesn't have the toolbox to specify Link caches in proper detail but that's fine, we can do it.

content.body: (We already have to specify things like Location redirect limits)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: (We already have to specify things like Location redirect limits)

content.body: The Link header is not part of HTTP proper though, Location is.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The Link header is not part of HTTP proper though, Location is.

content.body: I think that's just a SDO split and does not reflect any interesting architecture
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think that's just a SDO split and does not reflect any interesting architecture

content.body: It's the same SDO and that SDO has pulled in headers that are part of the core HTTP architecture into HTTP, so I'm not really sure you understand the setup...
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It's the same SDO and that SDO has pulled in headers that are part of the core HTTP architecture into HTTP, so I'm not really sure you understand the setup...

content.body: I think I understand the IETF's desired setup. I don't think it matches how the web actually works in browsers.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think I understand the IETF's desired setup. I don't think it matches how the web actually works in browsers.

content.body: Or how it is experienced by web developers
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Or how it is experienced by web developers

content.body: I don't think any web developer thinks of Link and Location and X-Content-Type-Options and Access-Control-Allow-Origin as on different layers of the stack.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I don't think any web developer thinks of Link and Location and X-Content-Type-Options and Access-Control-Allow-Origin as on different layers of the stack.

content.body: And I don't think they should have to
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: And I don't think they should have to

content.body: And I don't think that reflects any implementation split (in web browsers at least)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: And I don't think that reflects any implementation split (in web browsers at least)

content.body: Web browsers actually have that kind of split quite a bit (and match Fetch far less than would be ideal)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Web browsers actually have that kind of split quite a bit (and match Fetch far less than would be ideal)

content.body: That is not my understanding of the Chromium and Gecko codebases.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That is not my understanding of the Chromium and Gecko codebases.

content.body: I agree that web developers might perceive things differently
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I agree that web developers might perceive things differently

content.body: The main split there is renderer vs. browser/network processes
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The main split there is renderer vs. browser/network processes

content.body: And that largely has to do with whether stuff should or needs to be accessible to the main thread
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: And that largely has to do with whether stuff should or needs to be accessible to the main thread

content.body: E.g. ACAO (Fetch-level, not HTTP-level) stays in the network stack, and this helps against Spectre defenses.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: E.g. ACAO (Fetch-level, not HTTP-level) stays in the network stack, and this helps against Spectre defenses.

content.body: Both Chrome and Gecko wrap network code with a bunch of Fetch thingies
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Both Chrome and Gecko wrap network code with a bunch of Fetch thingies

content.body: Yep, but their headers are implemented all over the place, e.g. a lot of stuff supposedly in Fetch is in the network code.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yep, but their headers are implemented all over the place, e.g. a lot of stuff supposedly in Fetch is in the network code.

content.body: The layering is not based on specs, it's based on security mostly.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The layering is not based on specs, it's based on security mostly.

content.body: And some of it has shifted over time, that's fair, but I don't think browsers necessarily represent an ideal architecture either ðŸ™‚
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: And some of it has shifted over time, that's fair, but I don't think browsers necessarily represent an ideal architecture either ðŸ™‚

content.body: For sure, I don't think there is a single ideal architecture, it depends on your goals. Security vs. aligning with web developer expectations vs. writing well-factored specs across SDO boundaries are all different goals.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: For sure, I don't think there is a single ideal architecture, it depends on your goals. Security vs. aligning with web developer expectations vs. writing well-factored specs across SDO boundaries are all different goals.

content.body: It'd be interesting to know if web developers expect `Link` headers to take effect when you use `fetch()`
content.formatted_body: It'd be interesting to know if web developers expect Link headers to take effect when you use fetch()

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: It'd be interesting to know if web developers expect `Link` headers to take effect when you use `fetch()`
It'd be interesting to know if web developers expect Link headers to take effect when you use fetch()

content.body: I suspect they wouldn't expect that when using it in Deno or Node.js and I kinda doubt they expect it from browsers, but who knows
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I suspect they wouldn't expect that when using it in Deno or Node.js and I kinda doubt they expect it from browsers, but who knows

content.body: Deno has some similar stuff for import(), but yeah I dunno about fetch().
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Deno has some similar stuff for import(), but yeah I dunno about fetch().

content.body: (It'll auto-fetch types based on certain headers.)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: (It'll auto-fetch types based on certain headers.)

content.body: What would `Link` headers in fetch even do?
content.formatted_body: What would Link headers in fetch even do?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: What would `Link` headers in fetch even do?
What would Link headers in fetch even do?

content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: preload and preconnect
